Major events[edit source]

Month Day(s) Event
January 1 Ian Livingstone, co-founder of Games Workshop and president of Eidos Interactive, was knighted for his service to the online games industry.[1]
4 Monster Games, notable for the NASCAR Heat series and Excite Truck, was acquired by iRacing.com Motorsport Simulations.[2][3]
10 Take-Two Interactive announced its intent to acquire Zynga for $12.7 billion.[4]
17 Tencent acquired Sumo Group for $1.3 billion.[5]
18 Microsoft announced that it would be acquiring Activision Blizzard for $68.7 billion.[6][7]
31 Sony Interactive Entertainment announced that it would be acquiring Bungie for $3.6 billion.[8] The deal was closed on July 15, 2022.[9]
The New York Times Company acquired the viral browser game Wordle for an undisclosed seven-figure sum.[10]
February 14 Focus Entertainment completed its acquisition of Leikr Studio.[11]
16 Nacon announced its intent to acquire Daedalic Entertainment.[12]
22 Tencent announced its acquisition of Inflexion Studios, developers of upcoming game Nightingale.[13]
24 Nintendo announced its acquisition of long-time development partner SRD, with the deal closed on April 1.[14]
25 Tencent announced its acquisition of 1C Entertainment.[15]
March 2 Netflix announced its intent to acquire Finnish video game developer Next Games for $72 million.[16]
Epic Games announced its acquisition of internet music company Bandcamp for an undisclosed amount.[17]
8 Atari SA acquired online video game database MobyGames for $1.5 million.[18]
14 Embracer Group acquired Dark Horse Media, the parent company of Dark Horse Comics and Dark Horse Entertainment.[19]
21 Sony Interactive Entertainment announced its intent to acquire Haven Studios, making it the first development team of Sony in Canada.[20]
2125 The Game Developers Conference was held in San Francisco, California.[21]
24 Netflix acquired mobile game developer Boss Fight Entertainment.[22]
31 Entertainment Software Association announced that E3 2022 was canceled, both in-person and online.[23]
April 13 Beamdog was acquired by Aspyr through the Embracer Group.[24]
May 1 Embracer Group announced its intent to acquire the assets of Square Enix Europe, including studios Crystal Dynamics, Eidos-Montral, and Square Enix Montreal along with associated intellectual properties from Square Enix for $300 million.[25]
5 IMAX closes deal with The Game Awards and Summer Game Fest to have the events be shown in select theaters in the United States, Canada and United Kingdom.[26]
10 Electronic Arts formally withdrew from its license with FIFA after nearly 30 years.[27][28]
23 Quality assurance testers at Raven Software formed the first union within the U.S. video game industry.[29]
June 1016 Due to the cancellation of E3 2022, several presentations similar to it were made, including shows in association with the Summer Game Fest.[30]
July 12 Nordisk Games announced its acquisition of Supermassive Games.[31]
14 Nintendo began acquisition of animation studio Dynamo Pictures, with plans to rename it to Nintendo Pictures.[32]
18 Sony Interactive Entertainment announced that it would be acquiring Repeat.gg, esports tournament platform.[33]
August 1820 Quakecon will be held as a virtual event.[34]
1821 The first Pokmon World Championships to take place in Europe (specifically London), instead of North America since its inception in 2004.[35]
2428 Gamescom is planned to take place both as a physical event at Koelnmesse in Cologne, Germany, and online.[36]
September 1518 The Tokyo Game Show is planned to take place both as a physical event at Makuhari Messe in Chiba and online.[37]
December TBA The Game Awards 2022 will take place.[26]

Other events[edit source]

Ukraine support[edit source]

See also: 2022 boycott of Russia and Belarus  Video games and esports, and Non-government reactions to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine  Video games

During the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine launched in February that year, several video game developers and publishers with ties to Eastern Europe provided support for Ukrainian aid.[38] On February 24, 11 bit studios pledged to donate all profits earned over the following seven days from This War of Mine (2014) and its downloadable content to the Ukrainian Red Cross.[39] CD Projekt Red donated 1 million zloty (about 182,000) to the Polish Humanitarian Action group.[40] Embracer Group donated $1 million to Red Cross, SOS Children's Villages, and ACT Alliance, among other charities.[41] SCS Software donated over 20,000 to "multiple charities", and is working on new DLC for American Truck Simulator and Euro Truck Simulator 2 to raise funds for Ukrainian charities.[42] The Pokmon Company and Niantic announced they would donate $200K each, alongside an addition $75K raised by Niantic employees, to organisations such as GlobalGiving to provide humanitarian relief in Ukraine.[43][44] In addition, Niantic announced the suspended availability of Pokmon Go, Pikmin Bloom, and Ingress in both Russia and Belarus.[45][46]

Electronic Arts, Microsoft, and Activision Blizzard, among others, halted sales of physical and digital products into Russia during the conflict.[47][48] Electronic Arts announced on March 2 that it had started the process to remove the Russia national football team and Russian football clubs from its FIFA series as well as removing the Belarusian and Russian national teams and their club teams from NHL 22.[49] In addition to preventing purchase of their games in Russia, Nintendo announced on March 9 that Advance Wars 1+2: Re-Boot Camp, a tactical war game with a faction based on Soviet-era Russia, would be indefinitely delayed due to "recent world events".[50][51][52]

Two game bundles offered by itch.io and Humble Bundle raised over $6 million and $20 million for Ukraine aid support, respectively.[53][54] Epic Games made all proceeds from Fortnite during the last two weeks of March 2022 go to charitable aid for Ukraine, and raised over $144 million.[55][56]

Abortion rights support[edit source]

After the June 2022 U.S. Supreme Court ruling in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization, which overturned Roe v. Wade and eliminated the protected right to abortion, several video game companies affirmed they would offer their employees abortion benefits, including the ability to travel to states with protected abortion rights if necessary. Such companies include Microsoft, Bethesda, Ubisoft, Devolver Digital, Daybreak Games, Naughty Dog, Insomniac, Electronic Arts, and Bungie.[57]

Notable deaths[edit source]

  • January 4 Russell Lees, 60, narrative writer for Ubisoft and the Assassin's Creed, Far Cry, and Watch Dogs series.[58]
  • January 5 Stewart Gilray, 51, founder of Just Add Water, developer of the Oddworld series.[59]
  • February 28 Kim Jung-ju, 54, founder of Nexon.[60]
  • March 27 Mohammad Fahmi, 32, creator of Coffee Talk[61]
  • March 29 Scott Bennie, 61, developer writer for multiple role-playing games including the Fallout series[62]
  • April 26 Robert "Razerguy" Krakoff, 81, co-founder of Razer Inc.[63]
  • May 9 David Ward, 75, co-founder of Ocean Software[64]
  • June 22 Bernie Stolar, 75, former president of Sega of America, founder of Sony Computer Entertainment of America[65]
  • June 30 Technoblade, 23, American YouTuber[66]
  • July 6 Kazuki Takahashi, 60, creator of Yu-Gi-Oh[67]
  • July 15 Robert Alan Koeneke, 62, creator of Moria[68]
  • July 24 David Warner, 80, film, theater and television actor that also provided several video game voiceovers[69]
